Problem:
Consider a linear integral transformation given by \\(I[f(t)] = \\int_{0}^{\\infty} K(t, s) f(s) ds\\), where \\(K(t, s)\\) is a kernel function. We investigate the impact of a control function \\( h(s) \\) added to the input function \\( f(s) \\), resulting in a modified input \\( f(s) + h(s) \\).

If \\( h(s) = 0 \\) (i.e., no control function is applied), and the transformation is allowed to work on just \\( f(s) \\), will \\( I[f(t)] \\) be the same as when \\( h(s) \\) is not zero?
Explanation: With \\( h(s) = 0 \\), the integral transformation directly evaluates the impact of \\( f(s) \\) without modification. Introducing a non-zero \\( h(s) \\) modifies the input, thereby altering the resulting transformation output due to linear superposition properties.
